How Trump’s Big Ag bailout is alienating his MAHA base
items.description:
At a White House roundtable last Monday, president Donald Trump, alongside Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins and a handful of other leaders in the government, announced a $12 billion farm aid program intended to offset the economic blowback that U.S. farmers have faced this year as a result of the president’s volatile trade policies.

The move is par for the course from the administration, which has allocated a near-record total of $40 billion in farm subsidies this year, with at least two-thirds of those payments having gone to commodity farms. But Trump’s latest billion-dollar bailout does much more than funnel even more cash into Big Ag, which accounts for a significant share of the roughly 10 percent of total greenhouse gas emissions released by agricultural activities nationwide.

The corporate handout is also adding kindling to a feud brewing within factions of the right wing in American politics.

After COP30, Indigenous advocates celebrate gains while warning of unfinished work
items.description:
The COP30 climate conference in Belém, billed as the “Indigenous COP,” was defined by the organized presence of Indigenous activists, who staged protests and demanded inclusion in negotiations. Their advocacy led to tangible successes, notably Brazil’s promise to demarcate more Indigenous lands and the U.N.’s formal recognition of Indigenous rights, including Free, Prior, and Informed Consent, in the Just Transition Work Programme.

Despite these gains, Indigenous advocates were profoundly disappointed by the ultimate failure of U.N. member states to commit to a specific plan to stop relying on fossil fuels, with oil-rich nations watering down the final text. Leaders affirmed that the crucial fight for climate justice and land rights will continue through grassroots resistance, legal action, and future international forums, extending beyond the U.N. conference halls.

items.title: Zillow deletes climate risk data from listings after complaints it harms sales
items.description:
In September last year, Zillow, the largest real estate listing site in the U.S., introduced a tool showing the individual risk of wildfire, flood, extreme heat, wind, and poor air quality for 1 million properties it lists, explaining that, “Climate risks are now a critical factor in home-buying decisions” for many Americans.

Zillow has now deleted this climate index after complaints from real estate agents and some homeowners that the rankings appeared arbitrary, could not be challenged, and harmed house sales.

“The risk doesn’t go away; it just moves from a pre-purchase decision into a post-purchase liability,” said Matthew Eby, founder and chief executive of First Street, the nonprofit climate-risk quantifier that had provided the on-site tool to Zillow.

But assigning climate risks to individual properties has been controversial within the real estate industry. Some experts have questioned whether such judgments can be made at such a granular level.

EV sales are way down. Here’s why that might not be a big deal.
items.description:
According to the latest data, electric vehicle dealers sold about 20 percent fewer used electric cars in October than in September and saw a 50 percent drop for new ones. The question now is whether this dip is a sign of a prolonged slump or a mere blip in an otherwise upward trajectory.

While only time will tell, many analysts believe that electric vehicle adoption in the United States will continue to grow — albeit maybe not at the same pace seen before Congress killed the credits and automakers started second-guessing themselves.

Eliminating the federal credit of $7,500 on new EVs and $4,500 on used ones is certainly taking a toll. But the price of batteries, and thus cars, also continues to come down, and used models are becoming more of a bargain. Additionally, some states are trying to step in to fill the void the federal government has left.
